The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Sunday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express to Switerland, Paris and London, leaving venice at 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieate every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste- Vienna- Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cario will find special through carriages and language-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
div.p: As was to be expected, the news of the projected bombardment of Akaba has received an official denial. The question of Tabah - not of Akaba, which is unquestionably Turkish—will be decided, if anywhere, at Constantinople and we believe that Sir Nicholas O’Conor’s representations will finally persuade the Ottoman Government to withdraw its troops from Tabah and the Nekb el Akaba. But though the incident will, we believe, be terminated to the -satisfaction of the British and Egyptian Governments it must not be supposed that we shall hear no more of the Sinai frontier question. On the contrary, unless that frontier is properly delimitated further incidents of this sort are probable, especially when the completion of the Damascus Aleppo-Birejik and the Eregli-Birejik lines link Constantinople and the Anatolian provinces with the Red Sea. We admit the difficulty of persuading the Porte to come to any agreement as to the delimitation of the frontier, and we realise that strong action on the part of the Home Government may throw the Porte into the arms of a rival European Power—a result that our statesmen obviously cannot desire.

The desire of the Ottoman Government to make Akaba a supply base for the Hedjaz railway is natural and laudable enough, and in view of recent events in the Yemen we can understand that the Porte is extremely anxions to safeguard its position in Arabia by every means in its power. It is possible, therefore, that British diplomatic representations may be regarded with a certain amount of suspicion at Yildiz for the myth of British and Egyptian designs on Arabia and Syria has been sedulously propagated in the Turkish Empire. But, after making all allowances for Ottoman mistrust, the foot remains that the Tarkish troops have crossed the Egyptian frontier and have refused to evacuate the positions which they have occupied and that the Government of Egypt and the British Government, which has important interests to defend in this country, cannot, out of deference to the Sultan,abandon their demand for the evacuation of the district now occupied by his troops.

div.head: THE PRINCE TOUR !
div.p: "The Daily Telegraph,” in a leading article, reviews the tour of the Prince and Princess of Wales in India, and adds the following interesting comments on the visit to Egypt. Remarking that the tour is not concluded with the farewells said in India, the journal alludes to the call which the Renown makes at Port Said "to give the Royal,party an opportunity of seeing at least a few of the wonders of Egypt” Some of those wonders date back to the most remote periods of antiquity—a thousand yeas are to Egypt no more than a hundred elsewhere in the Old World, and no more than ten in the New —others belong to the last few years of our own time. The latter stand to the credit of a handful of Englishmen rather than to the credit of England. No one can be particularly proud of the Egyptian policy of British statesmen during the critical eighties of last century, and for some years later. They did not know their own mind, and waited on events. Happily for England, however, there was one Englishman in Egypt who did know his mind, and British statesmanship has since retrieved its reputation by giving him its implicit confidence. The regenerate Egypt, which is now the envy and wonder of the world, is the handiwork of Lord Cromer, assisted, as he has been, by a succession of brilliant men, trained under his direction. In spite of the Capitulations, in spite of persistent opposition offered in the early years by other nations, in spite of the enormous debt by which Egypt was saddled, and the evil tradition of Ismail’s ruinous extravagance, in spite of the entirely anomalous position of the British resident and the British Government in a country nominally independent, save for the suserainty of the Saltan, Egypt has been recreated on a sound financial and commercial basis. The prosperity of the country has leaped up in the last demule, and for the first time for centuries the wretched, downtrodden fellaheen have had their full share in the bounties which have been scattered along the Nile Valley. Where the fellah earned two piastres he now earns three ; the Government have rescued him from thelooal usurer, reduced his taxes, and raised the tide and overflow of the Nile, on which the welfare of Egypt has always depended. To the south, the great provinces of the Sudan have been reclaimed from the most atrocious savagery, and a railway now runs from the Red Sea across the waste of sand to the new capital which has risen on the ruins of Gordon's Khartoom. The work is not yet finished. Indeed, it has but just begun. Hardly more than the foundations, in the opinion of those who have faith in Egypt's fata re, have been laid, and vast schemes of irrigation will take many years and many millions before they can be carried into effect. But the triumph already achieved is a splendid monument of what capable Englishmen oan do in the way of governing men, if they are not hampered by interfering politicians 'at home. The Prince of Wales does well to conclude his Indian tour with a visit to Egypt. But for India there would be no British Agent in Cairo ; but for Indian experience it is hardly conceivable that Englishmen would have been able so soon to set Egypt on her feet again. The visit of the Prince and Princess is the best compliment that can be paid to the organising genius of Lord Cromer.

The annual general meeting of this institution will take place on the 10th April at the Qrand Continental Hotel at 6 p m.
The Salary Question.
The employes of Minieh Moudirieh have petitioned the Ministry of Finance, asking it to hare pity on them and to increase their salaries.

The annual performance in aid of the Armenian Benevolent Society of Alexandria will be given on Sunday next, 1st proxo, under the patronage of the Khedive, when Aerael will be staged.

The annual general meeting of the Alexandria Cricket Club will be held on Thursday, 29 th inst, at 5 pm., at the British Consulate. Business : general ; accounts ; election of officers ; collective subscriptions.
An Egyptian Modal,

It is stated that the diplomatic body at Tangier is to be constituted into a committee of international control on the model of the Egyptian Debt Commission. This proposal is raid to have come from Italy.
Concert.

A concert of unusual interest will be given at the Khedivial Hotel on Friday next, when Mme. Landi, the well-known local artiste, will present a select programme of vocal music with the co-operation of her pupils.
Tourist Steamers.

The white star liner Republic is due to arrive at Alexandria tomorrow afternoon with a large number of tourists. and will leave again for Naples at 8 p.m. on Wednesday, making the passage in under three days.
Property Sale.

The heirs of the late Sami Pacha Baronni have just sold for L.E. 46 000 to the New Egyptian Company the estate their father possessed at Rodah, including a palace and park of eight feddans. The highest previous
offer was L.E. 35.000.
Cotton Seed for Turkey.

The Sublime Porte has decided to purchase in Egypt a quantity of cotton seed of the very best quantity and to distribute it to the farmers of Adana. Aidin, and Salonica. It is the intention of the Government to entirely reorganise the system of cotton growing in these vilayets.
British Recreation Club, Cairo.

The annual general meeting of the Cairo British Recreation Club will be held on Wednesday, 18th April, at 6 p.m. In accordance- dance with Rule 14, the president, Crookshank Pacha, and the following members of the executive committee retire at the annnal general meeting and, being eligible, offer themselves for reelection—Messrs. W. F. Camilleri, H. Curtis, J. Grant, F. Phillips, and Geo.Walker.
Paul Kochantkl'a Recital.

Before a well-filled house last night at the New Khedivial Hotel, M. Paul Kookanaki, the celebrated violinist, with whose success in both Alexandria and Cairo our readers are well acquainted, bade farewell to an Egyptian audience. M. Kochanski gave his final performance and, it goes without saying, scored a final success. His hearers were throughout the programme held in a trance, and the applause at the conclusion was such that he had to oblige with an extra number. We hope that this distinguished young violinist will not be long before he pays this country a visit again.

London. Monday.

Subject to confirmation by the shareholders, the directors of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, have deoided to pay a dividend of 2s on the Ordinary shares (being at the rate of 20 per cent. on the paid-up capital) and of 10s. 9d. on the Deferrred shares. After writing off all the preliminary expenses, paying the debenture interest, and placing £102,000 to the reserve, the carryforward amounts to £9,200. The shareholders' meeting has been fixed for April 11.

This is a very satisfactory result on the first year’s working of this company, and we must congratulate the members of the local board on the unvarying success which has attended their efforts. The working year has, it must be remembered, practically been only of nine months' duration, considering the time that was taken up in the necessary preliminary arrangements. Moreover, the final call was only in October.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Board of Directors of the National Bank of Egypt has just decided to erect a fine building to house the bank's offices at Alexandria. An excellent site has been purchased from Messrs. Rolo in Toussoun-street, close to Cherif Pacha-street. The property is about two thousand square pics in extent.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: According to the latest news, the Turkish Government is still considering the demand of the British Ambassador at Constantinople, and it is hoped will comply with this demand. We understand that no definite refusal has been received from the Porte.

There is no reason to apprehend any farther collision in or near the disputed territory on the Golf of Akaba. The Tarkish troops, though they have been increased, have made no farther movement, and we understand that the personal relations of their officers with the British and Egyptian naval and military officers on the spot are very friendly.

div.head: TO ABOLISH QUARENTINE.
EXPERIMENTS AT ALEXANDRIA.
GAS FOR FUMIGATING SHIPS.
div.p: This morning some highly important experiments were made on board the S.S. Prince Abbas, of the Khedivial Mail Steamship Company, in order to demonstrate the practicability of abolishing quarantine in Egypt by destroying all microbes, microorganisms, insects, and vermin in the holds and cabins of vessels by means of gas without any resultant damage to the fixtures, bedding, clothingi etc.

Similar experiments to the one which began this morning have been taking place within the last few days at the Government Hospital at Alexandria in order to show the Sanitary Administration and the Municipality the efficacy of the system. In this instance Dr. Gottschlich has microbes, bugs, mosquitoes, et hoc genus omne in test tubes plugged in cotton wool, and then again embedded in the centre of mattresses. In every instance the microbes were sterilised and the insects killed.

One experiment gave great satisfaction. The gas was simply blown into the building where the bedding, etc., were exposed,with the result that all the living organisms hidden therein were rendered innocuous.

In this morning's experiments on board the steamer the gas was blown into the hold. The identical system has been adopted by many shipowners of the world for it is extremely practical not only as a disinfectant bat as a fire-extinguisher, as exactly the same systems is used for fire-extinguishing as for diainfecting.
This morning’s experiments were watched with great interest by a number of officials of the Quarantine Board and of the Khedivial Mail Company.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: (From our Correspondents).
Suez, Monday.

The D.O.A. steamer Prinz Regent is due at Suez next Thursday morning at 3 o’clock with the Duke and Duchess at Connaught on board. The vessel telegraphed from Aden for quick despatch in order that the Duke of Connaught might meet the Prince and Princess of Wales.
The dock station, where their Royal High­nesses will land, is beautifully decorated, and a landing stage is being made for the occasion.

On the occasion of the arrival of T.R H. the Prince and Princess of Wales in Cairo at 5 p.m. on Thursday, the 29th inst., the British and Ezyptian garrisons in Cairo will line the streets by which T.R H. will pass from Cairo railway station to Abdeen Palace.
The route will be as follows: Railway Station Square. Pont Limoun, Midan Babel-Hadid, Sharia Nubar Pacha, Sharia Kamal, Midan El-Opera. Sharia Abdin, Midan Andin as far as Abdeen Palace.

The above street will consequently be closed for carriage traffic (with the exception of carriages of persons going to the station to meet T.R.H.) from 4.45 p.m. till such time as the troops shall have been dismissed.
The public are requested to help the police in their task on this occasion by obeying their orders and not attempting to out through the lines of troops.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL WORK.
div.p: In yesterday's issue we gave a detailed account of Professor Flinders Petrie’s discoveries at the Temple of Onias. The other work of the British School, beside Professor Flinders Petrie's researches described on page 5, includes his excavation of a Hyksos cemetery and a great fortress of a new type, and his discovery of the remains of a temple of Rameses II. in the region of Sucooth. The Rev. J. G. Duncan’s work has opened a cemetery at Tell Yehud containing burials of the second century a.d., under Syrian or Jewish influence ; also he has examined a fortified town of Ramesaide age near Belbeis which contains large granaries. Mrs. Flinders Petrie and Mr. T. Borier Stoney have prepared drawings of all the objects found in those sites. These results of the work of the school must await description later.

div.head: SCARCITY OF HOUSES.
GOVERNMENT EXPERIMENT.
BUILDING HOUSES FOR ITS OFFICIALS.
div.p: The following communication has been made to the Press :—

During the past year the inadequacy of the exiting house accommodation in Cairo has made itself increasingly felt, and numbers of Government officials with fixed incomes find that their rents have been raised to a figure so high as to be practically prohibitive, or that they are simply served with notice to quit. In the latter case it is always difficult and some­times impossible to find suitable accommodation elsewhere.

Possessors of urban land seem desirous of holding on for a rise and the possibility of resale at a profit rather than of utilizing their land at once for building purposes. There would therefore appear to be no reason to anticipate that the inconvenience will be overcome in the near future by the ordinary operation of the law of demand and supply.

As it is obviously undesirable that Government employés should be compelled to pay rents beyond their means or, in the ease of those holding the more responsible posts, to find houses at such a distance from the Ministries as to be inaccessible if their presence is suddenly required, it has been decided by the Ministry of Finance to proceed forthwith to the construction of a few experimental houses on Government land at Ghezireh, to be let to Government servants at rents representing an adiquate return on the capital expended.
The boilding of some sixteen or eighteen houses of three types at rents of £150, £105, and £200 per annum, as well as two sets of flats at £100 to £120 per annom will be entered on at once.

Though these rents will be beyond the means of any but the better paid officials, it has been found impossible, in consequence of the high value of the Ghezireh land, to fix them below these figures. It is hoped that the hooses will be ready at the end of the year ; the flatts will require considerably longer to complete. The houses will be held on a yearly tenure.
Should the experiment prove to be a success and should the want of proper accommodation still regain acute, the shceme will be farther extended.

Applications from officials desirous of renting the new houses must be addressed not later than April 10 to the Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Finance. In case more applications are received than can be dealt with this year, the Ministry of Finance will decide as to what measures shall be taken to ensure an equitable distribution; the Government is aware that the present experiment will not benefit the smaller officials.

With their case it is far more difficult to deal and it can indeed only be properly dealt with by private enterprise. A concession has lately been given to a company on very favorable terms for the creation of a suburb beyond Abbassieh, and it is hoped that as soon as the tramway is completed officials on small salaries will be able to find houses there in sufficient numbers and at a moderate rent.

Should this unfortunately prove not to be the case it will be for the Government to consider what steps can usefully be undertaken to ensure adequate housing accommodation for this class of its servants.

div.head: TELEPHONE COMPANY OF EGYPT
div.p: Tha delays in telephonic communication complained of recently by the Cairo public are caused, we are informed, by the fact that the difficulties of operating are very great at the present time on account of the renovation of the machinery of the switch­boards at the central exchange of the head office, which ameliaration has been going on since June and has to be done at night gradually so as not to entirely interrupt the service. It is expected that this work, which will cost over £1,000, will be completed in a few weeks, when, without doubt, there will result a great improvement in the general working of the service.

We learn that the new list of Cairo subscribers for the present year ought to have been distributed in January but owing to a strike of printing hands of the firm in Cairo who undertook the work and contracted to deliver there handbooks by the 31st December last, there has been a great delay, but they will now be ready for delivery to subscribers early next month.

We are farther informed that, like all old established concerns, the Telephone Company has been losing lately many of its oldest and most efficient hands through offers of higher pay elsewhere hy the numerous new companies lately started in Egypt, who require employes with local knowledge and linguistic attainments.

It is interesting to note, as showing the immense progress in commercial matters going on in this country lately that the figures show the number of telephonic communications on the Cairo and Alexandria system of the company to have increased by quite fifty per cent, since last winter

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Indian Prince from Manchester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Monday, and is due at Alexandria on Friday.
The S.S. Sailor Prince left London on Monday and is due at Alexandria via Malta on April 11.

div.head: THE SUEZ ROAD.
POSSIBILITES AS A MOTOR TRACK.
SUEZ TO CAIRO IN FOUR HOURS.
div.p: A Suez Correspondent, signing himself "C.C.,” writes as follows : —

When one considers the ever-increasing number of motorists in Cairo at the present time, and the difficulty of getting a really good ran, it is somewhat surprising that the Suez Road—the old Anglo Indian mailronte— should have received so little attention. Here we have a magnificent stretch of road, some 80 feet wide, and over 80 miles in length, which might be made one of the finest motorcourses in the world ; at pretent, however, in some places, the surface is strewn with loose stones; in others, the way lies through heavy sand, and through the rough beds of former watercourses.

From a motorist's standpoint, owing to the flatness of the country, and the absence of any obstruction to the view, this track posesses advantages unobtainable elsewhere. The keen, dry air of the desert should also be an inducement to these who visit Egypt seeking health and for those who desire variety, there is more than a suggestion of novelty and freedom in the route, which remains much the same as described by Burton in his "Pilgrimage to Al-Madinah and Mecca” fifty years ago.

Still may be seen standing the ruins of 15 halting places, some of which were built by Waghorn, when he planned this highway to the Bast in 1830. Also the summer palace of Abbas Pasha— grandson of Mahomed Ali — opposite the 8th station from Cairo, and known as Dar el Baida. Two stations farther on is the tomb of Sheikh Takroori,the Pilgrim's Tree, and 18 miles from Suez, the old Fort of Adjroud, in Barton’s time considered to be the ‘‘Key to Suez.”

Its charm, however, lies in the open desert with its exhilarating atmosphere. For some 25 miles from Cairo the road ascends to a vast undulating plain, known to the Bedouins as the Wadi Jeffrs, which extends for 20 miles or more, after which the ground slopes very gradually to the sea. A more perfect course for motoring could hardly be imagined. Were it repaired, perhaps some enterprising person would start cars on hire during the tourist season, and the trip across the Arabian Desert to the Red Sea might then become one of the many excursions from Cairo.

I first explored this road with a companion in March, 1909, on a bicycle. It was then in a very bad state, being intersected by numerous dry watercourses. In 1903 these gaps were filled in—I think by the Khedive —and the repairs remained until 1905.

On the 25th ult. for the fourth time, I took the desert track to Cairo, on this occasion on a motor bicycle, and found it in many places cut up by watercourses involving heavy labour in crossing them. In some of these sandy spots the tracks of a motor car which visited Suez last autumn, and apparently had great difficulty in getting along, were still visible.

Could not the Automobile Club be induced to take the matter up, and put the road into thorough repair? The Suez Cycling Club has made a track to Adjroud, over which one can average 90 miles an hour. Were the track equally good throughout, the distance between Cairo and Suez oould be accomplished by motor in less than four hours.
Sixty years ago, the Indian mail despatches need to be sent from Suez to Boulac in five and a half hours by this road.

div.head: DEPARTMENT OF MINES.
div.p: The prospecting license granted to Mr. E. G. Wilis, of 22 Argyll Mansions, Addison Bridge, Kensington, London, by agreement dated the 18th day of April, nineteen hundred and five, has been surrendered by letter of the licensee dated the 16th day of March, of the current year.

div.head: EGYPTIAN AUTO TRANSPORT CO.
div.p: A new motor traction company has jest received the Khedivial sanction under the style of the Egyptian Auto Transport Company. The capital is to consist of L.E. 20,000 in four thousand ordinary shares of L.E. 5 each. There will be also 1 500 deferred shares which will be shared among the founders. The four thousand ordinary shares have been subscribed as follows George Adamidi, 450 ; Emile Charreyrrn, 450; Basils F. Homsy Bey, 600 ; Guillanme Kaul, 875 ; Youssef Saddik Bey, 550; Edwin Simond Bey, 500; and Aristide Théodordis, 75.
The first board of directors will consist of Messrs. Emin Karsm, Henry Maltaas, Guillaume Kaul, Clément Castro, and Edwin Simond Bey.
The objectof this company is the transport of persons, leasts, and merchandise by automobile.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut.-CoL R.C.C. Cox, commanding, and officere 2nd Batt, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will perform the following selection of mosic on the Terrace, National Hotel, on Wednesday afternoon from 4 to 6 :—
Marsh—Die Gordo dor Mark—Kruger
Overture—Tancredi—Rossini
Song—Still as the Night—Bohm

Valse—The Flower Show—Coote
Dance—Arabian —Sarakowaki
The Irish Patrol—Puerner
Selection—Lady Madcap—Reubens
Regimental March—Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
R. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster.
The Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll, on arriving last week at Naples from Egypt, prcceeded to Rome.

A brilliant and successful dinner was given by tbe Prime Minister, H.E. Mustepha Pacha Fehmy, at the Savoy Hotel last night. The diplomatic representatives of the Powers, the Ministers, Advisers, Under Secretaries of State, and principal heads of departments were invited, and moat were able to accept the Premier’s invitation, covers being laid for over a hundred guests.

The retirement of Mr. Bellamy Storer, the United States Ambassador at Vienna, who has been lately travelling in Egypt, is stated to be the result of strong disapproval expressed in the American colony there with regard to Mr. Storer's action in keeping too exclusively to aristocratic circles. It is urged that the retiring Ambassador was by no means sufficiently democratic to please Americans in Vienna, and it was remarked at the time that he even absented himself from Vienna on Thanksgiving Day. Mrs. Storer, it is stated, showed marked leanings towards the Clerioal party, and it is pointed out that Mr. Storer was honoured some little time back with a distinction which has never hitherto been aocorded to an accredited diplomatist, in that the Archduke Franz Ferdinand dined with the Ambassador.
The Hon. Bernard Rollo, formerly of the London agency of the National Bank of Egypt, has joined the firm of Messrs. Steer, Lawford and Co., stock brokers, Draper’s Gardens, E.C.
Mr. Baggallay, K. C., having hastened to England from Egypt, has undergone an operation and is progressing satisfactorily.
Mr. David Garrick Longworth writes that possibly he may be coming to Egypt from Nairobi in about a month’s time.

The estates of the late Thomas J. Emery, the American millionaire, who died in Egypt in the month of January, which has been admitted to probate in the town of Middletown, is valued at about 310,009,000.

The appointment to the Survey Department of the Sudan Government of Mr. R. Campbell Thompson, formerly assistant in the Oriental Department of the British Museum, is another proof of the thorough manner in which Lord Cromer is organising the staff for the administration of the Sudan. Mr. Thompson, who has hitherto been chiefly known as an Assyriologist, and whose works on Babylonian Astrology and Demonology have gained him a great reputation, is, however, a master, of other branches of Oriental study—including Ancient Egyptian—and is thoroughly compeitent to take charge of the work. He has gained experience in practical exploration daring his recent work on the mint of Nineveh, where he worked with Mr. King on behalf of the British Museum.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel. Ramleh : Col. and Mrs. H. Littledale, the Misses Littledale, India; Countess Baverden Bleuken, Berlin ; Dr. and Mrs. Brnnyate, Cairo ; the Etrl and Coonteis of Meath and snite, London ; Mr. and Mrs. B. Saunders. div.head: IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
EAST AFRICA GOVERNMENT.
WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION ACT.
div.p: London, March 26.

House of Commons.—Mr. Winston Churchill announced that he did not propose to introduce a representative Government in East Africa at present, but Lord Elgin was considering the question of introducing some form of Crown Colony Government. Any suggestions regarding the development of the country would receive fall consideration.
Mr. Morley said that he was unaware of any negotiations on the subject of the introduction of Indian coolies into the Transvasl.
Mr. Gladstone has introduced a Bill extending the Workmen’s Compensation Act to practically every person working for his employer, including seamen but excluding clerka and domestics. (Reuter)

This extension of the scope of the Workmen's Compensation Acts of 1897 and 1900 is quite logical for, if the principle underlying the Act is to be carried to its logical conclusion, the provisions of the Act must be extended to all accidents, whether caused by misconduct or not, and to all trades and industries.

The great principle underlying the provisions of the Act, was that the trades and industries of the country should he chargeable with the maintenance of those workmen who were injured in the carrying on of those trades and industries, and with the maintenance of those who were dependent upon the earnings of the injured workmen. To a certain extent, no donbt, the Act has achieved its object.

So far as the Act is concerned the trades and industries of the country are only made chargeable through the instrumentality of the individual employer, because it is the individual employer who is personally responsible to the injured workman. The liability thas imposed upon employers has been met by different kinds of insurance, the bulk of which is transacted by the existing accident insurance companies.

The latest figures to hand of the working of the Act are those for 1904. The number of cases under the Workmen's Compensation Acts dealt with in England and Wales by county court judges and county court arbitrators was 1.780 in 1904, the largest number yet recorded. The number his steadily increased from 999 in 1899.

The great majority of claims were, of course, settled by agreement. Even in cases of death, in which large sums would generally he payable, not more than 25 percent came in any way before the courts. £80,281 was awarded on account of death—an average of £177 10s. Id. each case.
Of the olaims for compensation finally fettled in 1904 within the compensation of the courts, the decision in 1,207 cases was in favour of the applicant, and in 269 in favour of the respondent.
ln 452 cases the compensation was awaided on account of death ; and in all of them the deceased bad left dependants.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
ON NE BADINE PAS AVEC L'AMOUR AND LA NUIT D'OCTOBRE.
div.p: ( From a Cairo Correspondent. )

M Le Bargy was, if possible, finer than ever last night (Saturday). His Perdican is a great part, growing in interest through the play, till the climax of intensity arrives at the end. The fountain scene with Rosette, etceped in 'irony' for the audience—the Greek irony is carried out to the fall when Perdican next meets Camille —was pure charm, Rosote playing up to her lover in the most admirable fashion. Indeed, Mile. Demsamond was most excellent throughout in that part, thoroughly naive and adoring, without comprehension. The other parts are more or less comic after their kind, and were broadly and fairly well interpreted. It is a singularly perfect play, in diction and situations, a very model of drama intensifying from calm to climax with its successions of gaiety and sorrow, love and remorse after understanding. Mile. Barety was, of course, all that Camille should he, disdaining her cousin's proposals "to order,” trying the sohool girl philosophy tests of his love and men's love in general, then changed by jealousy into woman, loving, then understanding, and finally renouncing. One wonders if those two would have remained apart in real life.

La Nuit d'Octobre we have already seen in Cairo. Mme. Moreno was the nurse and M. Monteux the poet. M. Le Bargy was, of course, infinitely superior ; the light and shade of his intonations throughout, and especially the music and power shown in his renunciation, which he calls nature to witness, marked his representation as a masterpiece, descriptive and imaginative to the highest degree. The sudden change of metre in this very renunciation enhancer the effect. Between Mile. Barety and Mme Moreno the contrast is more subtle and less obvious. Certainly Mile. Barety is more human, a woman impassioned, almost loving rather than exalting and inspiring. Her voice, too, is deeper and warmer, and her gesture more that of a "mortal.'’ What other word is there? Of course both gave to the fall the value of every syllable : but this certainly struck me as the distinctive feature. Mme. Moreno’s voice is higher in pitch, more silvery, with a "ring” in it, and possibly even more finesse in certain intonations, and this and her gesture seemed to give at once the impression of the immortal strengthening her poet, even by loving reproof. It would have been good to see her with M. Le Bargy.
But whatever this distinction, this performance was super excellent. La Nuit d'Octobre is a gem, and the setting was worthy of it.

div.head: LE DEDALE.
div.p: This was a very pronounced "dédale,” not at all easy to follow. The audience (I write without fear or hope that these lines will he read by those most conoerned) were more than usually trying. Something most be wrong with the ventilation to cause such constant coughing, but apart from that the lack of stillness and attention was always conspicuous, and alas ! the actors seemed to he well aware of it ; and much that had been at most foreshadowed in the first four performances was noticeable last night: the acting was overdone, much less "nuance” was perceptible, and less conviction—the performance was almost provinoial Of coarse M. Le Bargy and Mlle Baréty cannot help showing to advantage, bnt the difference could not be overlooked : they were not acting as they can but ; and their colleagues lapsed at onoe into the ultra "theatrical” in voice and gesture. It was a great pity, as it gives us less hope for the remaining performances. But it is not to be wondered at : when "overacting” and overemphasis receive more applause than real subtlety and fine delicate interpretation, the performers, however great they may be however thorough and devoted to their art, cannot be expeoted to exert themselves as they would before those who note and appreciate every slightest shade of appropriate inflexion and demeanour. Mile Bernon was good, and M. Danvillier was, for most of the time, more satisfactory than in Le Duel. Bnt as a whole the performance was disappointing : it might, if met half-way by the andienoe, have been so brilliant. We mast hope for better laok for the remaining nights. After all, the length of the play was possibly largely theoanse ; the strain of five aots perleotly presented would have been too scantily repaid.
From our Correspondent.
Three officers terving in Ireland, Captain W.H. King, 6th Inniakilling Dragoons, Dublin ;

Captain F. W. Woodward, D.S.O , lst Battalion Royal North Lancashire Regiment, Kinsale, and Captain J. L. Conry, 1st Battalion Connaught Rangers, Mullingar, have been chosen for service with ths Khedive’s troops in Egypt. Captain King was appointed direct to a captaincy in the lnniskillings in 1902 from subsitern in Roberts’ Light Horse, one of the South African irregular cavalry regiments, which good work in the campaign. Captain King was with it through the greater part of its career (Queen’s medal with two clasps, King’s modal with two clasps). Captain Woodward has served in the North Lancashires since 1893, and commanded a company for the past four years He was adjatant of the 1st Battalioa 1901-04, and earned hia D.S.O. in the defence of Kimberley, where a wing of the battalion formed the baokbone of the defence. He was signalling officer for the greater part of the siege, and in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, in- olading the actions of Lindley and Rhe-Noster River ; the operations in Cape Colony, and numerous minor affairs (mentioned twice in despatches, D.S.O., Queen’s medal with three olasps, King’s medal with two clasps). The third officer, Ciptain Conry, was with the gallant Rangers in hard fighting which marked Bailer’s advance to Ladysmith, including Colenso, Spion Kop, Tagda Hjights (where he was wounded), Vaal Krantz, and Pieter’s Hill, the last great fight oatsile Ladysmith ; the operations in Natal, the Transvaal, Orange River Colony and Cape Colony, io the congee of which he was again wonuded (thrice mentioned in despatches, D.S.O., Queen’s medal with five clasps, King’s medal with two clasps). He recently gave up the adjutancy of the lit Battalion.
Major H. D'A. Harkness, Whelch Regiment who served with the Egyptian Army for some years, has been promoted lieutenant colonel of the 2nd Battalion at Quetta, Bombay.

Another officer well-known in Egypt, Captain Evelyn Fitz G. M. Wood, son of Sir Evelyn Wood, has been spedally promoted major in the 1st Royal Dragoons, Lucknow, from the Devonshire Regiment. Major Wood, who earned distinction in Arianti and South Africa, had always a predielction for the mounted service, and a good deal of his service has been passed in staff billets. His gallant father was originally a midday in the Royal Navy, and whist serving in the Crimea fancied the light cavalry, and the navy lost a good youngster and the army got one of the best cavalry leaders that ever rode at the head of a regiment.

All the Imperial troops have been withdrawn from the Dominion of Canada, and the garrison at Halifax and Euqnimalt are manned by Canadian troops. A number of Imperial officers have been permitted to remain in Instructors in various departments, matter of opinion whether the final Tommy Atkins from Canada is a wise procedure whilst it is admitted that the abolition of the North America Squadron is a mistake, which may yet call for rectification.

It seems that the cruiser Donegal, Captain W. J. Grogan, was harder hit than at first supposod when she grounded off Suez recently. She will be repaired at Malta pro tem., but but will not proceed to the China Station, whither she was bound when tho accident occurred. Her sister cruiser Monmouth has been ordered to complete for sea and proceed to the China Station at onoe. The Monmonth is in the Reserve, and recently completed a commission in tho Channel Fleet.

The battleship Venerable has arrived at Chatham from tho Mediterranean. She will be recommissioned for another tarn of service there, and will take on Rear-Admiral Bridge man and his staff to Malta, where he joins as second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet.

div.head: A GLOOMY FORECAST.
div.p: Lard Digby, speaking at Dochester, complained of an increasing lack of patriotism throughout the country. He predicted that our rain would come about, not throngh poverty, but throngh affluance. A great number of men of the npper classes spent their time in amnsing themselves, and had no patriotism. And the lower class, who went now by the name of the "work shy” class, seemed to live upon the people who had money. The country would before long be forced into conscription.

div.head: THE SULTAN AS NATURALIST.
div.p: The Sultan of Turkey has. the "Scotsman” hears, developed a considerable interest in natural history, and, oddly enough, Seems to be particularly interested in the mineral products and fauna of Australia He is bent on forming a collection of si ch thiugs from that part of the world, and commisions have been recently exeouted on hsi behalf with the objeot of getting together a representative aeries of minerals and preoions stones, os well as a collection of the birds of Australia.

div.p: April 22nd to May 2nd, 1906.

The Khédivial Mail Steamship "Ismailia” will he despatched from Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Monday, April 16th, for Piraeus is direct ; and should sufficient passengers offer, the vessel will make a second trip from Alexandria on Friday, April 20th.

The vessel will retarn from Pine on the conolasion of the games op Thursday, May 3rd, hot holders of return tickets will have the option of returning by the Company's mail steamer of April 26th, should they so desire.

(A reduction of 25% on the fares (excluding cost of food) will be allowed to holders of "bons collectifs" of the Olympian Games Committee). During the stay of the vessel at Piraeus from April 22nd to May 3rd, first and second class passengers will be allowed to sleep on board on payment of P.T. 50 per day first class and P.T. 40 per day second class, which will include meals but notice of daily meals required must be given one day in advance to the Chief Steward.
Early application for accommodation should be made to the Company's office in Alexandria, or to the principal Tourist Agencies.

div.head: COAL AND GOLD IN EGYPT.
THE CAIRO SYNDICATE.
div.p: The following ingennoaaly framed article is from the "Financial News” :--

A couple of months ago attention was directed in these colnmns to the growing in proveraents of thfc Egyptian coil indnstry. It was pointed out that at present the coil which is consumed in the Land of the Pharaohs has to be imported at great coast, and, in addition, a supply has to be procured for the vessels at Suez and Port Ssid, which are making use of the world’s greatest waterway. These considers ions render it self-evident that if the coal reionroea of Egypt could be developed op to each a point as to render the country independent of ontside assistance in the matter of fuel, a great advanoe would have been made, and a profitable indnstry would have been opened up to exploitation.

This is the view which was taken by the persons who were responsible for the formation of the Cairo Syndicate. They considered that if the property acquired by that company were anything like whet it reprinted it to be nothing it was nothing short of a national asset, and - its development nothing less than a matter of national concern ; for they had a concussion which is estimated to aggregate 80.000 square miles, within eight days of London, and easily accessible from the coast. And although of this vast area only the central portion has so far been examined, the discoveries up to the present are reported to inolnde coal, copper, and promising indications of payable gold. At the moment, the ooal me wares are regarded ar the best of the assets; but there n no knowing how well the others may turn out, especially as the gold-bearing area is believed by the company's engineers to inolade the site of the historic Ophir Mines. Samples of the coal have arrived in London, and the tests made are stated to show it to be of excellent quality. It should be added that some oil has been fonnd to exist at points on the property ; but it is at the moment impossible to say what value may ultimately be attached to this additional asset. At present, the oil resources may be regarded merely as a make weight, though, as everybody knows, oil resources have a way of showing themselves in the most unexpected manner, and making themselves the foundation of the moat colossal fortunes. The Cairo Syndicate has had a report from its representative on the properly. His own words will tell the tale better than it can be told in any other way:--

"The coal bearing strata is at the present from 8 or 9 to 12 in. in in thickness, and the coal I easily detached from the country rook. When we shall have reached the main seam I am confident we shall have reached the main seam I am confident we shall have a clean one, with well-defined over and under clays. We may reach it in days or, perhaps, weeks, but, having no sata to go upon, it becomes a simple question or pick and drill and patience.

"That the venture is now something more than a prospect is certain, and fully warrantsthe expenditure of some capital. As an example I should like to work with three shifts of men each twenty-four hours. I can only afford one shift of nine hours. With three shifts I coild develop rapidly. At present it is bat slowly. Until I can leave the work with safety I cannot examine the country between here and Akabah ; but one piece of good news I have gleaned out from an Arab who comes from the place, viz., that it is only three days’ march to the coast, where, he says, there is a kind of port, Darned ‘Dahabil,’ and that it is downhill all the way. This must be so, as the tannel month is 2.750 ft. above sea level. A drop if that extent is 35 miles to the ocean, will be of enormous advantage in the event of a railway being built, as haulage of loaded trucks will be reduced to a minimum.

Thas far of the coal. The gold resources of the concession are, perhaps, even more likely than the coal to strike a sympathetic and romantic chord in the breast of the investor. In this case samples of tailings from snoient damps have been sent home and assayed to Mr. Artbar Clandet (Assayer to the Bank of England), with the result that the four samples show gold to the extent of 18 dwt., 15 dwt, 17dwt.. and 18 dwt. respectively. There assays refer only to the tailings ; bat farther samples of the actual quartz, which hears evidence of considerable richness, are said to be now in the hands of Mesers. Johnson, Matthey and Co. The sample came from mines on the property of the Cairo Syndicate, which are conveniently aitaated as regards tbe Red Sea and have a good supply of drinking water. What is regarded as the proved gold and other mineral bear-ing land covers an area of three or four square miles ; but it seems there is do reason for believing this to be the fall extent. Anyhow, an enormous amount of work has been done in the past on the property, but only done with the result of doing little more than "scratching the surface," owing to the very primitive engineering knowledge and appliances which were at the disposal of the ancient miners. A depth of 60 ft. to 100 ft. sems to have been the limit and all the work has been done with hammer and small, round pointed gouge.

Here, then, is an ancient goldfield, which may piossibly have been the source of some of the great wealth of the Oriental despots of the past, now being opened up for the benefit of British enterprose and the British inverstor. At least, the British inverstor can go into it if he cares to do so; but he need not to trouble unless he likes, for the company's engineer says that the money necessary for the purpose can be raised in Egypt and Syria at the present momont. He adds, in conclusion, the emphatic statement that "this mine will pay handsomely, and the Cairo Syndicate not only posesses a mine, bnt really a goldfield.” If the cautious East is so willing to go into the enterprise, there is little wonder that the impnlsive and enterprising West as represented by the Cairo Syndicte, has thrown itself with vigour aud with energy into the task of development.

div.head: KHARTOUM 1856-1906.
A RETROSPECT.
ABBATE PACHA'S INTERESTING LECTURE.
div.p: The above was the subject of a lectare delivered by H.E. Dr. Abbatî Paoha under the auspices of the Société Khedrviale de Géogra phie on Saturday afternoon last in the presence of the Govenor of Khartoum (Staunton Bey) and a moat distinguished audience. So great was the concourse of auditors that many had to reunin standing daring the delivery of a lectare if exceptional interest. The span of life allotted to mortals and the limits imposed by age upon human faculties rarely permit an individual to speak of events half a century old with a vividness of recollection and an elaboration of detail as if they had happened yesterday. It was this which lent exceptional interest to the remarks of Dr. Abbate Pacha, but it was not this alone.
Auddience Spellbound.

The details themselves were related with such force and precision that the audience—composed largely of ladies—abso lately spellbound. For a whole hoar and a half we learned to ba accompanying the traveller upon his two journeys, undertaken under ciroumstances of the greatest diversity. In 1856 Dr. Abbate formed part of the suite whioh accompanied on his desert trip Saïd Pacha, and many wore the fatigues aod adventures encountered by those who journeyed to Khartoum in those distant days. A picturesque account was given of the Korosko desert enlivened by one or two amusing incidents, as, for instanoe, when, at last, the Nile was reaohed and amidst rejoicings the expedition halted upon its banks, the late Zuficar Pacha invited some of his companions to be seated upon what seemed to be a piece of black rock but subsequently turned out to be a sleeping crocodile !
Then and Now,

Khartuam upon Dr. Abbate’s former visit was but a collection of hots with a mission garden in the centre and a Government House which formod a kind of caravansary. And now —whit changes and transformations, have taken place! The old city is no longer recognizable. Gordon’s headquarters has become the most European of capitals in Central Afrias. It is in every sente a modern dwelling-place where few Orientals reside. Indeed, in his soconnt of Khartum Dr. Abbate did Dot differ in substanoe from Mr. Edward Dicey, who described it as the city of "magnificent distance". Omdurman was next passed in review. It still retains most of its former characteristics and is occuoied chiefly by the natives of the Sudan. But even there British civilisation and habits have penetrated, for, strange as it might appear the black battalions might be seen playing football and cricket. Abbate Pacha had a goos word to say for the Sudanese women, who are hard working and industrious. They still far outnumber the men- who are lazy lords of creation- owing to the protraced and decimating war which culminated in the overthrow of the Mahdi.
Tribute to Gordon

The lecturer paid an extremely elequent tribute to the heroism of Gordon and ascribed the foundation of the Sudan’s regeneration to his glorious martyrdom. The recent journey to Khartoam in a "train de luxe" was then contrasted with that of half a century provions. That trip was undertaken at the traveller’s own expense and from a sheer desire to compare ith former impressions. Dr. Abbate’s praise of the present administration was in every respect unqualified, and, coming from such an independent source. it most be undoubtedly well-marited. Altogether the lecture was one of the most enjoyable we have attended, and delivered by a man in his eighty fourth year, in a dear voice and without a traoe of fitigue towards the end was a veritable tour de force.” A letter was read from the Sirdar (Sir Reginald Winagate) expressing his regret that he was unable to be present. This was but fitting homage to one who has for so many years laboared in the cause of humanity and civilization.

div.head: KHARTOUM LABOUR MARKET.
BUILDING AND HOUSING.
div.p: The building trade in Khartoum is at prewsent so brisk and the call for building materials is so heavy that a remarkable rise in the prices of skilled labour and materials has been the result. By the end of this year the time limit for quite a number of plots will expire and owners are expediting building operations so as to leave Government no room for complaint or, what is worse, confiscation. It has been observed that in spite of the high cost of building the new houses are more substantial and in better taste than the earlier efforts for providing accomodation. This desirable result is due to the rise in the price of land justifying larger investments in buildings.

The labourer class finds it hard to procure accommodation in Khartoum. One could suggest Omdurman for the homing of this class on account of the cheapness in time and mory such a move would entail, the cheapest rate of transport between the two towns b ing P.T. 2 per day per had averaging a total of P.T. 52 per working month. The only other alternative in view of this difficulty would be for Government to insist upon a higher scale of building iu the 3rd class quarter of Khartoum. But such a step would be open to criticism as people purchased land there ia accordance with terms approved by the Government and it would not be so easy to alter these terms unless come inducement be held out. ( ‘Sudan Times.”)

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SCARAB.
div.p: AN INTERSTING WORK.

Nearly everyone who comes to Egypt nowadays buys one or more specimens of the little stone beetles known as Soarabs; but few who do have any clear idea of what scarabs were made for, or why one scarab should differ from another in value a fact out of which the dealers suck no small advantage. To all such unlearned buyers, Mr. Newberry’s book will come as a godsend ; for his twenty years’ reputation as an explorer is a sufficient guarantee for the accuracy of its information, and it is impossible tor anyone to rise from a perusal of the hundred pages whioh accompany its liberal allowance of forty five plates without a very clear idea of the several varieties of scarab now extant and of their meaning. Mr. Newborry will have nothing to do with any new-fangled theories about scarabs being used as money, but says at once that Dr. Birch was right when be laid down years ago, that they were seals and nothing but seals. He also shows by many excellent and clear examples how, before the use of keys came into fashion, seals were used for the purpose of sec ring many things which prudent people now keep locked np, sach as wine aud provisions. Hence, he thinks, a scarab or seal engraved with ths first owner’s name or device, was once as necesary an appendage to a good housekeeper as the bunch of keys was to tbe careful matron of the last centnry, and he mentions in support of this that whenever scarabs have been found in graves, the occupant of the tomb has nearly always proved to be a female. He traces also the gradual evolution of the Egyptian seal from the cylinder which the first conquerors of Egypt seem to have imported from their Asiatic home to the finger-ring, often consisting of a scarab mounted on its longitudinal axis, from whioh came in turn car modern "signet” rings. For scarabs were not in use during the whole period of pre-Christian Egypt’s florescence. Mr. Newberry tells ns that althongh a few occur at the end of the end of the sixth dynasty, they only came into fashion daring the twelfth and disappeared soon after the twenty-sixth. Why this should have been is only one of the many puzzles whioch Egypology has for us.

In the twelve hundred or so specimens of which Mr. Newberry here gives excellent reproductions, every possible variety beems to have been included. By far tbe greatest number bear simply the. names of their owners, or at most their names and titles, and the Royal Superintendent,” "singing ladies,” scribes, and priests to whom they once belonged, doubtedless used them for signing letters or authenticating deeds. More rare, as might ecxpeetcd, are the scarabs belonging to Royal personages, which were, no doubt, generally broken when their owners died as tbe "broad seal” of England still is at the demise of the Crown. Rarer still are those which bear the names of gods the purpose for which a god could use a Real not being very obvious, although it is, of course, possible that his ministers might require it now and then for the alienation of Church lands. More common, again, are those scarabs which are engraved with no name, bnt merely with a pattern of more or less intricacy. Snoh patterns were, no doubt, like tbe trade mark still used by men of business, and might suoceed in persuading the purchaser of merchandise that he was, in the language of the advertisements, getting what he asked for. Yet there are a few specimens iu Mr. Newberry's plates which seem to fall into none of the categories but to have been made for ornament merely. Such are the few which bear "wishes ” often singalarly I modern in tone, such as "May Ptsh give a Happy New Year, from the Prince Shashanq (the Egyptian form of the Biblical Shishak, by the way) to his mother, Ka-ra ma ma,” or the one or two huge ones five or six innhes long, made by command of the great Pharaoh Amenhotep III to commemorate his marriage with Queen Thyi, and the enormo is "bugs" that he made when he wont hig game shooting after lions and wild cattle, Perhaps the modern objeot whioh most olosely corresponds to this last kind is the medal.

Finally, Mr. Newberry assures his readers that, although there is occasionally a little "faking” of the glaze over difficult to detect, there are hardly any altogether bogus or forged scarabs. Such objuots, he thinks, would require skill aud knowledge far bnyond that possessed by the modern dealer, and the expense of manufacture and importation would be prohibitive. A comfortable saying, yet the prioe of rare scarabs is rapidly rising, and we suspeot that before long the supply is likely by such means to catch up the demand.

div.p: The competition for three silver badges awarded by the N.R.A. for competition among last year’s "Skilled Shots” took plcoe last Saturday with the undermentioned resalts. Weather conditions were not favourable to high scoring. The strong oross wind rendered it more than usaally difficult to find and keep the small 6-in. "ball” at 200 yards, and at 600 yards the varying light farther inoreased tho difficulties. The scoring was remarkably close throughout. The Earl of Meath honoured the club with a visit daring the afternoon and evinced great interest therein.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 26 Mare.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais eat resté, samedi passé, in varié à 90 1/2. L’Unifiée a baisse de 1/4 à 106 et la National Bank de 1/3 h 28. La Daïraet l'Agrioole sont demeurées inohangéea k 18 8/8 et 10.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Fonoier Egyptien a reactionne de 1 franc a 798. La Banque d'Athenes s'est maintenue a 151.

Notre marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin, pen d’aotivité. Les transactions n'ont pas été nombreuses sur les grosses valeurs ; les petites ont été, par oontre, traitées dans one bonne mesure, notamment vers la fin de la séanoe.

La National Bank, négligée, est revenuek 28 l’aotion ancienne, et 27 3/16 la nouvelle. L'Agricole, asset animée, s’est maintenue à 9 16/16 L’action Crédit Fonoier s’est inscrite à 798, et l'obligation 1886 & 336. La Daira a faibli h 28 7/16. La Béhéra a clôturé k 87 1/2-88.
L’Immobilière a réaotionné h 385. L’aotion Agrioole du Nil est revenue & 282 ; la part de fondateur a avancé à 9.

L’aotion Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a’est raffermie h 4 1/4—5/16; la part de fondateur k L.B. 16—17. La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development est remontée 17 1/2. Les parta de jooissanoe Eaux du Caire ont fait 277. .
Dana le groupe des Hâtais, les Nnngovicb ont avanoé k 17 1/4—3/8 et les Baehler k 6 16/16.

Parmi laa petites valeurs, les Delta Land se aontinrarita k 8 7/16-1/2 et les Hooker k 1 1/8. En bonne tendanoe également, les Qlyme- nopoulo ont avanoé k 1 9/16. Les Estates sont restés en olCtnre k 21/16 après avoir atteint 2 1/8 an début de la séanoe. Les Abdy ont fait 1 8/8, las Walker and Meimaraohi 0 7/8 et les New Egyptian 36 sh. 3.

A l’assemblée générale extraordinaire de la National Bank of Egypt, qui sera tenue le samedi 14 avril prochain, h 3 h. 80 p.m., il sera proposé, comme on sait, de réduire k oinq ans la durée dn mandat do gouvernement et de porter k 22 le nombre maximum des administrateurs.
Or, nous apprenons qne les nonveaox administrateurs proposée sont Harari pacha et THoa. Sydney Peel, de Londres.

Nous sommes autorisés k déolarer qne la nouvelle reçue de Chypre suivant laquelle Sir William Willoooks aurait obtenu do gouvernement de l’ile une garantie indirecte de 4 % do oapital que TAgrionltural Bank of Cyprus engagerait en prêts aux cultivateurs, est dénuée de fondement.v
Cette rumeur n’a, tout an moins, reçu ioi auoune confirmation officielle.

Suivant des informations d’Alexandrie, la direotion locale de TEgyptian Trust and Investment (Glymenopoulo) aurait déoidé de fixer le dividende du premier exeroice k 2 sh. 6 par action, Bauf approbation do comité de Londres.
D’autre part, on assure que la Port-Said Salt Association annoncerait prochainement nn oou- pon de 6 %, soit S penoe par action de 10 sh.

A l’assemblée générale de la Sooiété Anonyme dn Béhéra, tenue le 20 mars courant, il a été déoidé de distribuer un dividende de P.E. 25 par action ordinaire, payable k partir d’aujourd’hui, contre présentation dn coupon N 9.

A la 1ère assemblée générale de la Sooiété Egyptienne d’Eutreprisee Urbaines et Rurales, tenue le 20 du courant k Alexandrie, il até déoidé de fixer oomme suit les dividendesk distribuer pour l’exercice 19' 6, dont la dorée a été de sept mois et demi : P.E 22 par action de oapital at P.E 42.8 par part de fondateur. Un solfie de LE 1,077 a été porté k compte convenu.
Les actionnaires de la Sooiété Egyptienne d’irrigation sont convoqués en assemblée générale ordinaire le mardi 17 avril prochain, k 4 h. 80 p.m., au siège sooial au Caire.
Ordre du jour : rapport do conseil; approbation des oomptes de Texercioe olosle 31 janvier 1906; remplacement d’administrateurs soc tanta, etc.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Caisse Hypothécaire d’Egypte sera tenue le 12 Avril prochain k Anvers. A Tordre du jour : rapport du oonseil d’administration, approbation des comptes et nominations statutaires.
Les cours du ooton sont arrivés en nouvelle hausse d’Amérique. Le dispouible a gagné avanthier 10 points, le Mai 12 et l’Octobre 7
Les arrivages ont été de 19,000 balles contre 28,000.
Le marohé de Liverpool est également en hausse.
Ici, le Mai, qui avait fini samedi passé k 20 8/8, a ouvert ce matin k 20 1/2 pour a l6 turer a 20 13/82.
Les Bureaux H. de Vriss et Bootigny ont été transférés me Kasr-el-Nil, ancienne Villa Fabrioiu» Pacha, presque en faoe la National Bank.

MM. H. De Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’exécution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sut lee marohés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York.
La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envovée sur demande.

div.head: L'IBRAHIMIEH PLOUGHING CO.
div.p: Suivant on confrère du Caire,"il n’est pas exaot qne la Société Ibrahimieh Hloughing ait l’intention de déposer son bilan. Le syndio de la faillite des Suoreries a demandé k oatte Sooiété de payer la somme dont elle est débitrice. De son côté, la Société de TIbrahimieh a demandé k la Société générale, le versement dn solde de la dernière émission. L’Ibrabimieh Ploughing est donc parfaitement en mesure de faire face a ce payement et a sés engagements couranta.

Nnngovich bey constituera une Sooiété pour l’exploitation de oes deux hâtela, auxquels on fait subir maintenant d’importantes améliorations. Etant donnée la hante oapaoité de M. Nungovioh bey, nul doute qu’ a la nouvelle Société est réservé le meilleur avenir.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aejourihti à midi et demie)
Les transactions sont presque] unites et la
ote oontinue k fléchir partiellement.

La National‘Bank tombe k 27 18/16 l’ancienne, k 26 7/8 la nouvelle, la Land Bank k 11/16, le Comptoir k 7 1/16, la DVira k 18 1/4, !a.Delta’;Land k 3 13/32, les Markets k 24/3, les Egyptian Hotels à 5 7/8.

Voioi la répartition des bénéfices, telle qu’elle sera proposée par le Conseil d’administration aux actionnaires de TEgyptian Estâtes Ce. : 2 shellings par notion ordinaire. Boit 20 % sur le oapital versé ; 10 shellings et 9 pence aux parts de fondateurs. Après avoir payé tous les frais préliminaires, ainsi que l’intérét des obligations et mis £102,000 k la réserve, il reste encore une somme de £9.200 k reporter k nouveau.

La tendanoe générale reste faible. Il est probable même que la réaction s’accentuera encore légèrement jesqu’k la fin dn mois par suite des liquidations en perspective. C’est lk un travail d’épuration qui profitera k la reprise d’avril.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
